status_message:
Make America Afraid Again! John Howell, an authentic voice from New Hampshire, raised on a farm in Missouri, and a veteran of '68 politics provides his take on the Republican Rantfest on Day 2.

As a survivor of the Dem and Republican conventions (and other national events) in '68, I've been having flashback dread re. this year's conventions. For those of us who are busy at work this summer and who are traveling for business, catching even only snatches of the doings in Cleveland has far surpassed those previous examples in unprecedented craziness. My highlights so far:

• General Flynn's Armageddon speech - I watched all of it, fascinated by his impression of Sterling Hayden doing "General Jack D. Ripper" in Dr. Strangelove. Great sequel to the original movie.
• Melania Trump's weirdly baroque words delivered with impeccable Slovenian accent in a neo-Frederick's of Hollywood outfit — words which turned out to be the product of others' eloquence (hers? a team? who?)
• General Giuliani's mashup impersonation of Jim Cramer at "Mad Money" manic best and Al Pacino's top overacting frothing (pick your movie and role). Someone should check his meds and/or his pacemaker.
• Finally, (and only so far — it's just Wednesday!), Ben Carson invoking Lucifer as Hillary's mentor. Talk about "the devil in the details". . .  why did Dr. Carson wait until he had lost in the primaries to announce this far out factoid? Might have done him some good when he was still in the running. 

And then there's the apparent termination (Fox-wise) of Roger Ailes, a man ultimately responsible for much of this media-centric nonsense. No public figure deserves disgrace more. 

I'm remembering when Esquire sent William Burroughs, Jean Genet, and Terry Southern (screenwriter of Dr. Strangelove) to "cover" the 1968 Democratic convention. Their truly skewed sensibilities delivered the most  tone-right insights into that mess, which was beyond the comprehension of mere journalistic mortals. (Look it up: http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/a4718/political-convention-0808/.  I would risk contact with Lucifer to revive their shades and send their subversive souls into the heart of darkness that is the Republican rantfest by the lake.

I read recently that scientists have discovered 1,300 previously unknown galaxies. Is it possible that some mysterious alien life-force has captured our media and that none of this is actually happening? Would that it were so—it would seem less bizarre, less strange, less uh, alien than what is coming across the airwaves.

Have you noticed that many of the pundits alternate looks between uncontrollable smirks and stunned deer-in-the-headlights deadpans? Houston, we have a very big problem.

      #######

John Howell is Editorial Director for 3BL Media, overseeing five international news and distribution websites; a partner in Howell Farms, Malden, MO, a 75 year-old family agribusiness; and a long-time supporter of Hillary and Bill Clinton.

status_message:
The Republican Nominee for President has preached hatred at Mexican immigrants ("They're bringing drugs. They're bringing crime. They're rapists.") and scorn at the Mexican Government ("There are several ways to compel Mexico to pay for the wall."). Trump and his supporters shake our relationship with Mexico and its citizens to the core. 

Today July 19 in San Francisco, along with Representative Pelosi and dignitaries from Mexico and California and San Francisco, we celebrated the groundbreaking for the Mexican Museum, an institution which by its very nature shows America and Mexico stand together.  Andy Kluger, Chair of The Mexican Museum, shared with Voices4Hillary how Trump's insults affect him and both countries he loves. He writes in English and in Spanish, so share his thoughts with friends who speak either language or both.

THE DAMAGE THEY DO
TRUMP, HIS SUPPORTERS and MEXICO
By Andy Kluger

In English

As the Chairman of the Board of the Mexican Museum, Smithsonian affiliate in San Francisco, a lifelong Democrat who votes independent at times, and a father and grandfather, I find myself very troubled.

I was born in Mexico City and grew up in the ABC community (American, British and Canadian). My parents, born in New York and Chicago, came to Mexico for career advancement in education and publishing. My sisters and I attended the American School and were privileged to receive a top education with terrific Mexican children along with expat kids. My worldview was formed by two cultures, American and Mexican.

Thanks to my parents' cultural life, I was privileged to grow up enjoying the visits of individuals such as Diego Rivera, Luis Bunuel, Eric Fromm and others. I joined in cross-national activities such as Boy Scouts, was part of the group that welcomed President Kennedy to Mexico, and participated in the USA pavilion of the World's Fair in Mexico. The warm relations between our two countries made me proud -- until this last year. 

I have in the last two years traveled to Mexico on museum business many times, and in my many conversations with Mexican counterparts, I find the mood between our two nations deteriorating in frustration.

There are never perfect solutions nor right replies but the angst felt by the population in Mexico about the presidential race is disheartening. The conversation in the expat community, the academic and cultural community and within Mexican families who are aware of the US situation revolves around the question, "Does not the population in the US understand the importance of a rational, thoughtful, experienced candidate like Hillary far outweigh even the slightest consideration of the consequences of a Trump presidency?"

"Do you Americans realize the dangers posed by a candidate that plays to people's fears as so many despots in Europe and Latin America have done?"

The real concern for those asking the questions also revolves around not just the candidate but the mass of voters supporting a candidacy by Trump.

We need to wake up and emphasize not the greatness of America which we do have, but the need to heal our schism!

In Spanish

Como Presidente del Consejo de "The Mexican Museum" afiliado a Smithsonian in San Francisco, demócrata de toda la vida que en ocasiones vota como independiente, además de padre y abuelo, me encuentro en una disyuntiva.

Nací en la Ciudad de México y crecí en la comunidad ABC (Americana, Británica y Canadiense). Mis padres, nacidos en Nueva York y Chicago, vinieron a México para avanzar en sus carreras de educación y publicaciones. Mis hermanas y yo asistimos a la escuela Americana y fuimos privilegiados en obtener educación de primer nivel con compañeros hijos de Mexicanos y de otros ExPats. Mi visión del mundo estaba formado por dos culturas, Estados Unidos y México.

Debido a la vida cultural de mis padres fui privilegiado en crecer disfrutando las visitas de individuos como Diego Rivera, Luis Buñuel, Eric Fromm y otros más. Además participé en actividades extracurriculares como Boy Scouts o ser parte del grupo que dio la bienvenida al Presidente Kennedy a México, el Pabellón de los Estados Unidos en la Feria Mundial de México entre otros. La cálida relación entre nuestros dos países me hizo sentirme orgulloso de ser parte hasta este último año.

He viajado a México durante los últimos dos años por cuestiones del museo con frecuencia, y en muchas de mis conversaciones con mis congéneres mexicanos encuentro que el clima entre nuestras dos naciones se deteriora en frustración.

No existe solución perfecta o respuesta correcta, pero la angustia que siente la población mexicana sobre la carrera a la presidencia de los Estados Unidos es descorazonadora. La comunidad "Ex-Pat", las comunidades académica y cultural y las familias que están conscientes de la situación en EEUU ronda sobre la pregunta "¿Es que acaso la población norteamericana no comprende la importancia que una candidatura racional, considerada y con experiencia como la de Hillary supera por mucho la mínima consideración sobre las consecuencias de una presidencia con Trump?"

"¿Es que los norteamericanos no se percatan de los peligros que representa un candidato que capitaliza sobre el miedo de las personas, como muchos déspotas en Europa y Latinoamérica lo han hecho antes?"

La verdadera preocupación de quienes plantean estas preguntas no es únicamente el candidato: es la masa de votantes que apoya la candidatura de Trump.

Necesitamos despertar y enfatizar no la "Grandeza de America" la cual tenemos, pero la necesidad de sanar nuestro cisma.

Andrew M. Kluger, J.D. is Chairman of the Mexican Museum, Smithsonian affiliate in San Francisco. Andy is an entrepreneur, business executive, venture capitalist and philanthropist. Former Chairman and CEO of Hawaii Air Ambulance, he is also the Honorary Consul of the Republic of Mexico to the State of Hawai.

status_message:
Voices4Hillary is pleased to present The Hillary We Know Executive Committee Member Evangeline Morphos' reaction to the #RNCinCLE day after a long day one. Have a look and share with your friends, if you dare.

THE MORNING AFTER
Day 1 of My Republican Hangover
By Evangeline Morphos
 
Like most political junkies, I've binge-watched television coverage of conventions for years, but the opening night of the Republican convention has left me, and the nation with a very bad hangover this morning. Despite the ridiculousness interlude of Melania's "trumped up" speech to humanize her husband, the message last night was that the Trump candidacy has hijacked the democratic system. 

Early in the afternoon on Monday chaos erupted in the Convention Hall as several delegates, part of a "Stop Trump" movement, pushed for a roll call on the convention rules. But the protest was quickly bullied down by the presiding officials, leaving the Republican Party with no way out of nominating Donald Trump as its candidate for the Presidency. 
 
The end of the protest was also the end of any mention of the word "Republican Party" throughout the entire evening. This is no longer the Republican convention—it is entirely Donald Trump's.  Not a single speaker used the RP word at any point. The Republican Party seemed to have dissolved into the branding strategy of Donald Trump's singular ambition.  
 
Traditionally, speakers on the kick-off night of the convention are political luminaries who energize the crowd and set the tone for down-ticket victories.  Last night the only "show" in a long list of "no-shows" was a corpsed-looking Bob Dole who looked sorely in need of one of those little blue pills he once promoted on television.
 
Monday night's roster was more like the list of guest stars for a re-boot of "The Love Boat" than speakers at a political convention--Has-beens and D-list celebrities like Scott Baio (whose last executive position was "Charles in Charge"), one of the guys from "Duck Dynasty", and Anthony Sabato (who, as the scroll below his image reminded us had done underwear ads for Calvin Klein) all dog-whistled ominous warnings about "Keeping America Safe" and lecturing us about "What it Means to Be an American".  Even the former Navy Seal, Marcus Lutrell, (the Lone Wolf) who might have had something real to say about veterans' issues, conflated war in Afghanistan with war in the streets at home with chilling certainty: "In order for any life to matter—we all have to matter. You hear? ….Your war is here."
 
The prejudice and divisiveness that has been Trump's message throughout the campaign turned from dog-whistle to trumpet with Congressman Mike McCaul's appearance. Although McCaul serves as Chairman of the House Committee on Homeland Security, he identified himself publically only as one of Trump's "national security advisers". There was not even a nod to the good people of the Texas' 10th District which he serves. McCaul's speech was about "taking back our country" –and it sounded more like a call to violence than a call for party unity. "We need to end sanctuary cities, keep dangerous people out of our country, and secure our borders once and for all."
 
McCaul's ugly rhetoric was echoed in subsequent speeches by Milwaukee County Sherriff, David Clarke, and former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani. Giuliani was particularly frenetic raising the spectre of our "enemies".  Giuliani, ended his speech with a warning to these enemies: "You know who you are, and we are coming to get you."
 
So much for the Republican Party's hopes of attracting new voters, and expanding its base. The Trump delegates, and supporters seemed lock-stepped in his alternative reality of an America crouched in fear and in danger every minute. 
 
A live commentary on 538.com reminded readers that the statistics that last night's speakers were citing were completely wrong—but what good did that do the terrified voters who were watching television instead of reading Nate Silver and his team of realists on the web.
 
This is clearly going to be a campaign built on fear, and one that  accuses both the Democratic Party and the Republican Party for allowing the danger to exist. The message last night was that only Donald Trump can protect America. The language used was sometimes apocalyptic, and sometimes messianic—but always focused on the singularity of the presumptive nominee.

That's why the convention had to be about Trump and not the Republican Party. Last night Trump configured the campaign not as a two-party system working its way through the democratic process; but as a mano-a-mano, single battle between himself and Hillary Clinton. Donald Trump knows he can't beat the Democratic candidate; but he does think he can beat a demonized Hillary Clinton. 
 
To that end, a parade of speakers came forward to witness how Hillary (and Obama) were responsible for the deaths of their sons and loved ones. Make no mistake, my heart aches for the real grief of these families—but let's get real. 

Accusing Hillary of killing people in Benghazi, accusing Obama of allowing people to be killed by undocumented immigrants and accusing the Black Lives Matter movement of  causing the murder of police officers is deranged logic and to "weaponize" people's grief is dangerously dishonest. The final two speakers ended the evening by joining the frantic chanting from the audience: "Lock her up!" 
 
Trump showed his hand last night. This election is a battle he is going to fight his way. He has left no room for advice from Republican leadership, and he has no room on his Brioni coattails for any other Republican candidates. It is also going to be a vicious fight, and it's going to be personal.  
 
(Oh, and yes—the beautiful, but hapless, Melania spoke last night. She was introduced by The Donald who appeared first in shadow and emerged to the strains of the illegally played "We Are Champions." Grabbing the mic like an aging lounge-lizard, Trump kept breathing into it: "We are gonna win so big."
 
Melania, for her part, had learned her speech. The fact that it sounded as if it was written by a college essay tutor, or a Miss Universe consultant was not her fault. But it turns out that even the banality provided by the speechwriter was unoriginal. Many of the sections were plagiarized from Michelle Obama's speech at the 2008 convention. We did, however, learn that as First Lady Melania would "help children and women."  Well, that's inclusiveness, I guess.)

Evangeline Morphos, is a theater, film and television producer who teaches at Columbia University. She often writes on television and new media.

status_message:
Voices4Hillary is pleased to recount the first day of #RNCinCLE with remarks by Tanya Melich. She is known as the first person to coin the phrase, "Republican War Against Women."  After what we saw in Cleveland yesterday, it seems that though that War is very much alive--did you read the RNC Platform? -- there are more targets too.

TRUMP'S REPUBLICAN PARTY
 by Tanya Melich
  
Watching the Republican convention yesterday made me physically sick.  Trump, guided by aides who had been Nixon acolytes in the Watergate scandal, had choreographed an ugly show of fear and hate.  The evening was described as "Make America Safe Again." It should have been labeled "Make America Frightened Again."
 
Trump presented a sinister production that reached its climax with the ranting of retired Army Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn who encouraged the delegates to consider America going to war so Trump could lead the nation to victory.
 
Flynn called on Hillary "to leave this race now" and like a high school cheerleader exhorted the delegates in sing-song chant: "Lock her up. Lock her up." ending with "Wake up America. You can't sit this one out".  (While he seemed to be referring to delegates working in the election, I got the sense he was also talking about a war on Islamists and illegal immigrants.)
 
Flynn reminds one of General Curtis Le May who wanted to use nuclear weapons against the Russians and was the prototype for the nuke-tough American general in the Dr. Strangelove movie. That Flynn is a defense advisor to Trump and was reputed to have been seriously considered to be Trump's running mate requires one to seriously pause.  Would Flynn be Secretary of Defense in a Trump administration?
 
Trump's crudeness and his lack of civil discourse that has been so visibly evident during his campaign was on display in his choice of other speakers.

To put a grieving mother who lost her foreign service son in the Benghazi attack on national television was cruel.  As she had all year, this mother blamed Hillary for her son's death.  The idea that Hillary caused his death and does not too mourn for Americans lost is ludicrous.
 
Probably the saddest performance of the evening went to former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani.  After rightfully paying tribute to law enforcement officers and saying that Americans of all types, races should unite, he raised the temperature in the hall by describing an America overwhelmed with crime and violence. (Even though the nation presently has an historically low crime rate overall.)
 
For the first time all evening, the entire convention was electrified.  Delegates rose to their feet as Giuliani in loud staccato phrases attacked Hillary and the Democrats for being soft on crime and promised, "What I did for New York, Trump will do for America." His performance was that of a classic demagogue and would fit nicely in books that categorize fascist rhetoric.
 
The Bushes, Mitt Romney, John McCain, John Kasich and all those other Republican leaders who decided not to attend this convention were right.  I'm sorry I took the time to watch the demise of what was once a respected political party.  It is now the means for a sick, power hungry man to satisfy his appetites.
 
Trump claims he won the most Republican votes in the primaries and thus is supported by the majority of his party. He is wrong. According to a July 16th article by Jon Ward, senior political correspondent for Yahoo "when the contested phase of the primary essentially ended in early May, Trump had roughly ll million votes compared to 17 million" for all the other presidential GOP candidates.
 
For nearly my entire adult life, I worked to elect Republican candidates and left
when the party turned against the rights of women.  The spectacle I watched last night was worse than anything I've ever experienced.  I was at the 1964 San Francisco convention when Barry Goldwater was nominated and walked out of the
l992 Houston convention when President George H.W. Bush with his Lee Atwater- led team turned the convention over to Pat Buchanan, Pat Robertson and Jerry
Falwell.
 
Cleveland is worse than San Francisco or Houston.  I don't know whether I have the stomach to watch the next three nights.  The party of Trump is a disgrace to the nation and must be particularly painful to those Republican delegates and members at home who watched as Trump orchestrated their party into the image of a pathological bully.  
 
America deserves better.  Monday night at the Cleveland Republican convention will be remembered as one of the meanest displays of crudeness and fear mongering in our nation's political history.
 
July 19,2016
   
Tanya Melich left the Republican party in 1998 over its official treatment of women and is now an independent.  She is the author of the 1996 acclaimed book, "The Republican War Against Women: An Insider's Report From Behind the Lines".  She is known as the first person to coin the phrase, "Republican War Against Women" that
has become a staple of political rhetoric.
 
 
 
.

status_message:
This is the 6th entry in Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices on Voices4Hillary. 

The final entry will be by Ann Lewis, a member of the DNC Rules Committee, when Hillary makes her choice. Let us know what you think of this series. Do you want to share this entry or the whole series with your friends?  Don't let us stop you. 
 
SUPERMAN NEEDED
Cory Booker for Hillary VP
By Elena Coyle
 
A lot has been said, not all of it positive, about Cory Booker's unusual compassion and human touch.  From moonlighting as Newark's most overqualified snow-shoveler, to literally saving constituents from a burning building, he has been dubbed a superman of sorts – first to Brick City, and later, to his state.  Ellen even (in)famously gifted him the costume to match.  We may roll our eyes, but we should not allow our own cynicism to blind us to who Cory Booker really is: a hero.  And we could use a hero right about now.

November portends the most important presidential election that many of us will ever see.  While this warning resurfaces each election cycle, something deep in our collective unconscious tells us that, it's true.  In the eleven months since the first Republican debate, we have witnessed the ascendancy of a candidate who threatens the very core of our constitution, civil rights and basic sense of human decency.  And all this at a time when our country has witnessed more heart-wrenching and unthinkable acts of violence than most of us can bear.  We are, more so than ever, waiting for our superman.

Cory Booker is as intelligent and he is deep – as qualified as he is humble.  Receiving a BA and MA from Stanford, a second MA as a Rhodes Scholar from Oxford and a JD from Yale, Cory Booker had any number of future prospects available to him, many of which could have be quite lucrative. But instead, Cory Booker chose to dedicate his life to the service of others – moving to Newark to start a non-profit organization that provided legal services to low income families. 

Like Hillary herself, Cory Booker has worked tirelessly throughout his career to improve the lives of our country's most vulnerable men and woman. At age 29, he was elected to Newark's City Council, and in 2006, he was elected Newark's Mayor; a post he held for 7 years. Then, in a 2013 Special Election, he was chosen to represent New Jersey as United States Senator. In 2014, Senator Booker was re-elected to a full 6 year term.
 
An effective mayor turned Senator, Cory Booker is as at much at home on Capitol Hill as among the smokestacks of Newark. Though he could not fully transform his city, beleaguered by decades of corruption and poverty, he never stopped trying. And what he did restore was hope in a place and a people that America forgot.  He brought hundreds of millions of private investment dollars to Newark – during the Great Recession no less. Through investment, economic development and social reform, he transformed a fallen city into a pillar of progress. 

And in the Senate, he continues the fight for New Jersey, and the country's least advantaged citizens, with the introduction and support of legislation advancing prison reform, gun control, education, healthcare and social welfare programs.  There is no doubt that he would carry this fight to the White House in continued support of these important causes.
 
Moreover, Cory Booker as the Vice Presidential pick would surely inspire people of color, who overwhelmingly support Hillary, to turn out to vote.  Cory Booker's presence on the Democratic ticket would also be a visible re-statement that the Democratic party is committed to diversity in the Nation's highest office.  

More than this, in no small way, the election of Barack Obama brought the hope of a dialogue among the races on the question of race. This dialogue, for many reasons beyond the President's control, never came to full fruition. But it is a necessary precursor to concrete policies that will resolve interrelated, systemic problems, like poverty, lack of educational opportunities and mass incarceration. The tragedies of Ferguson, Dallas and Baton Rouge are in part the consequences of our country's failure to directly confront the issue of race, and a reminder that we can no longer delay in doing so. As history has demonstrated, change is brought about not only by movements, but by leaders. Cory Booker has the perspective, experience and compassion to ensure progress.
 
As Vice President, Cory Booker would be not only an agent for racial harmony, but would stand in his very being for true racial equality – a standard that has eluded our country since the last generation took up this cause more than 50 years ago.
 
When I survey the unenviable task of rescuing our country from perennial war, income inequality and racial tension (among many woes) – quite frankly, this looks like a job for Superman.

Elena Coyle is a corporate transactional attorney with an active pro bono asylum practice.  She enjoys photography, running with her husband and teaching her daughters to raise hell.
 
Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices is curated by Annette Niemtzow, Editor and Ashley Emilia Chappo, Associate Editor.
 
Annette Niemtzow, Diane Slaine and Ted Smythe are the Editors of Voices4Hillary, a cross-platform Social Media project of The Hillary We Know.

This is the 5th entry in Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices on Voices4Hillary.  Do you want to share this with your friends?  Don't let us stop you.

A DREAMER FOR THE DREAMERS
The Case for Julian Castro as Hillary's VP
by Lisa Tejeda

Julian Castro is the future of our country.  
 
His life itself is a testimony to the fact that the American Dream is still alive and well at a moment in time in our world when many familiar ways of life have changed. 

Castro is a graduate of Stanford and Harvard Law School. At 26 he became the youngest city councilman in San Antonio's history, and subsequently its youngest mayor. He served three times as mayor of San Antonio, the country's seventh-largest city. At present Julian Castro is in President Obama's Cabinet serving as the Director of Housing and Urban Development. He is not yet 42. 

Julian Castro-  achild from a family of struggling immigrants, raised by a single mother, dreamed the dream, worked the work, and from the meek and humble a mighty young leader has risen!
 
Julian Castro can give voice to the American Dream, its weaknesses and triumphs. Our economy has changed from fabrication to automation. Office clerks and secretaries are replaced by computers, copy machines, and ever changing technologies. The economy has recovered, but there are many left behind. We have to remember the American Dream and rework it, and we need someone who can give real truth to its meaning.

Julian Castro has been the United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development since July 28, 2014.  Though many people may not be aware of this, HUD is a branch of the federal government with very broad reach. Its mission is to create strong, sustainable, inclusive communities and quality affordable homes for all Americans. Millions of people have avoided foreclosures through HUD. Veterans receive housing assistance through HUD. It is HUD which provides emergency housing assistance to many after natural disasters. Since 1934, HUD has administered FHA loans which have enabled many Americans to buy their homes, by guaranteeing their mortgages to lending banks. Every day, millions of Americans receive some small or large benefit through the existence of HUD.
 
As a member of President Obama's Cabinet, Julian Castro has had the advantage of being present at critical cabinet meetings. This has given him access and exposure to the many issues facing the nation which engage the entire cabinet and the President.

Julian Castro doesn't just understand the struggles of minorities. He is himself Hispanic. He knows the challenges many immigrant and minority families face because of their ethnic and cultural backgrounds. He is what Donald Trump wants white Americans to fear, and yet all Americans, regardless of ethnicity, will soon learn to love him.
 
His presence as Vice President will help heal the wounds that the Trump campaign has inflicted on our nation in the past year.

He will also help to attract Latino voters, who will constitute a critical demographic in November. He might even put Texas in play for the Presidential Election.
 
Julian Castro is young and this too is an enormous benefit. The Millennial Generation came out in force to vote in the primary election and now during the General Election they need a voice to connect with. They need a voice that represents their future, that is nearer in age and demographic to the life and society they will and do live in.
 
Millennials are now the largest demographic in the Unites States.  They have passed the Baby boomers. We cannot follow the example of the British with Brexit and disregard their voice or its power. Almost every other person being discussed for the Vice Presidency is over 55. They simply do not have the "life experience" to relate to the Millennials or the "rest of us."
 
To me, Julian Castro is the Vice Presidential candidate that Secretary Clinton should choose. I hope she does.

Lisa Tejeda is an architect, urban designer and urban planner  who has worked and lived in the U.S. Mexico City, Britain, and Ireland. She is the widow of a Mexican architect and has 1 daughter and 1 son who have Dual US-Mexican Nationality, 2 sons with U.S. Nationality, and 2 Mexican step-daughters. 3 of her children live in Mexico City, and 3, in the United States. She wrote this essay out of the deep conviction that this election will have tremendous impact on her family and her children's future.

Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices is curated by Annette Niemtzow, Editor and Ashley Emilia Chappo, Associate Editor.

Annette Niemtzow, Diane Slaine and Ted Smythe are the Editors of Voices4Hillary, a cross-platform Social Media project of The Hillary We Know.

Next up… Cory Johnson for VP by Elena Coyle.

This is the 4th entry in Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices on Voices4Hillary.

A WILD CARD CHOICE
RICH CORDRAY FOR HILLARY VP
by Nick Smyth

Ohio's Richard Cordray is the best VP option for Hillary.  Cordray can help Hillary get elected and can help her be an even more terrific president. Now the Director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), Cordray, age 57, has won statewide Attorney General and Treasurer elections in Ohio.  He can help Hillary in the critical Buckeye State - and well beyond.
 
I know Rich from the four years I spent working with him at the CFPB.  He would work tirelessly to help Hillary win the White House, would strengthen the ticket geographically and with critical constituencies, and would be a terrific VP, able to take on complex policy challenges and find novel solutions.  I know because I've seen him do it multiple times at the CFPB.  Cordray was brought to the CFPB by now-Senator Elizabeth Warren, when she was there building the new agency in Jan. 2011.  In Jan. 2012, when it became clear that Senate Republicans would never confirm Warren to serve as the CFPB Director, President Obama nominated Rich to serve as the CFPB's Director.
 
Rich went through challenging, vigorous and sometimes mean-spirited confirmation hearings – Senate Republicans and industry opponents wanted to find reasons not to confirm him, but couldn't.  Despite well-funded campaigns by the U.S. Chamber and others seeking to tarnish the new agency and its leader, they learned that Cordray has no "baggage" and he was ultimately confirmed by the Senate.

A whip-smart former Marshall Scholar, Jeopardy Champion, and U.S. Supreme Court Clerk (where he's also argued seven cases), Cordray has built the CFPB from a small team that landed on the consumer protection beachhead into an incredibly successful and effective advocate for consumers across the country - that has garnered broad bipartisan support. The agency has cracked down on abusive payday lenders, for-profit colleges, and companies that cheated veterans and service members; it has ordered banks and other financial institutions to return more than $11 billion to consumers who were subjected to illegal tricks and traps.
 
And despite forcing them to follow the rules, industry players describe Rich as reasonable and willing to listen. Rich has testified 30 times in front of hostile Republicans on the Hill, and he has always kept his cool, pushing back strongly and effectively against unfair attacks. He's an excellent debater and would enthusiastically serve as attack dog against Donald Trump's nonsense.
 
Rich has won local and statewide elections over and over in Ohio, with strong labor support in that critical state. Unlike any other VP candidate under consideration, he would appeal to both the "Warren wing" that includes many former and current Sanders supporters and the working class White voters that are essential to winning OH, PA, FL, and other key states.  Hillary can have all of that without having to sacrifice a Democratic Senate seat necessary to assuring what might be a razor thin majority.

   ####

Nicholas Smyth is Senior Counsel at a technology company in Pittsburgh and previously spent four years as an Enforcement Attorney at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

This is the 3rd entry in Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices on Voices4Hillary.

MY Choice for Hillary's VP. Sherrod Brown of Ohio
By Jan Bernstein
 
The VP choice. A choice for Hillary to veer left of center. A choice for Hillary to make clear where her other appointees and some policies may land. A chance to pick up state and electoral support. A chance to balance the Democratic ticket. 
 
My choice for her to pick is Sherrod Brown. He is the left leaning senior United States Senator from Ohio since January 3, 2007. In 2011, in the National Journal's annual rankings, Brown tied with eight other members for the title of the most liberal member of Congress.
 
Before his election to the Senate, he was a member of the United States House of Representatives, representing Ohio's 13th congressional district from 1993 to 2007.
 
On November 7, 2006, Brown faced two-term incumbent senator Mike DeWine in the general election. Brown won the seat with 56% of the vote to DeWine's 44%.
 
Brown stood for reelection in 2012, defeating opponent Josh Mandel 51% to 45%.

He is popular in Ohio and all through the Rust Belt--a feisty, down to earth person who connects with blue collar workers on trade and the economy. The  fact that his wife, Connie Schultz,  is a Pulitzer Prize winning journalist won't hurt with women either.
 
Yes, if Hillary picks him, Republican Governor John Kasich gets to pick a Republican to replace him, but we have to win the White House, and to win the White House, we have to win Ohio. If we win at the top of the ticket, the Democrats have a  good chance to win back the Senate even without Senator Brown from Ohio.

Hillary needs to reach white male voters in Ohio, Indiana, West Virginia, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and  Pennsylvania. Sherrod Brown is the best opportunity to build that bridge for Hillary and to convince blue collar workers not to vote against their own best interest in the upcoming election . The presumptive Republican nominee is no friend of  working people , and a Clinton- Brown ticket will make that fact clear, and will separate reality from reality tv. 
 
We need Sanders' left wing millennials too.  The other left leaning Senator being vetted, Senator Warren from the already blue Massachusetts delivers this demographic but not the other.
 
We elect Presidents by the electoral college. Therefore, may I repeat. It's Ohio. It's Ohio. It's Ohio. Clinton- Brown 2016.
 
Sherrod Brown for VP.  Take it away, John King. November 8, 2016.
 
Jan L. Bernstein, an attorney  practicing family law in New Jersey and New York, is a long-time supporter of Hillary Clinton for President. She lives in New Jersey.

This is the 2nd entry in Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices on Voices4Hillary.

BOLD AND BODACIOUS: HILLARY CLINTON AND ELIZABETH WARREN FOR PRESIDENT AND VICE-PRESIDENT

Gender equality took a grand leap forward when Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren joined forces in matching light blue - a bright and empowering image of two brilliant leaders enjoying their first shoulder to shoulder campaign appearance on June 27 at the Cincinnati  Museum Center. 

Elizabeth Warren declared:  "Hillary has brains, she has guts, she has thick skin and steady hands, but most of all, she has a good heart. And that's what America needs [and] that's why I'm with her!  You know, I could do this all day." Warren joined the fervent audience chant: "Hillary! Hillary! as the first woman presumptive Democratic Party nominee stepped up to the podium.  Energized and smiling, Hillary Clinton proclaimed, "You just saw why Elizabeth Warren is considered so terrific, so formidable — because she tells it like it is.  I have to say, I just love to see how she gets under Donald Trump's thin skin."   (Check out Warren's "queen of slay" Drumpf tweets.)

This high-spirited twosome kickoff set me and many others hoping for a Clinton-Warren ticket - a ground breaking one-two punch to the 228 years of U.S. male presidencies.  This team would be a powerful antidote to the charges that Hillary is too establishment.  Clinton-Warren as running mates, a huge symbolic smash through the glass ceiling,  would represent a dramatic change in the U.S. political scene.

Elizabeth Warren brings a clear economic-populist progressive bridge to the Sanders camp, working class voters, and independents.  Warren's anti-Wall Street perspective, consumer advocacy and opposition to the TPP would widen Hillary's wheel base.  Warren says, "Supporters of the TPP want you to believe this deal is about America's role in setting the rules of international trade. But here's the problem, TPP isn't about helping American workers set the rules, it's about letting giant corporations rig the rules."  Hillary's choice to have Warren run would reinforce for voters her opposition to the TPP which many continue to doubt.  

Their unifying trailblazing candidacy for President and Vice President of the United States is what our troubled grieving nation needs now.  They would reinforce each other's strengths and shared values, challenge each other's differences, and continue the urgent call for equality and justice.  

Two women on the ticket?  Hillary's 1969 Wellesley commencement address: "The challenge now is to practice politics as the art of making what appears to be impossible possible."  Let's go for it!

Clare Coss is a playwright, librettist and activist.  Her play, Emmett, Down in My Heart, about the events surrounding the 1955 murder in Mississippi of 14 year old Emmett Till, will be produced in German by Berlin's Afro-German Theatre, Label Noir, in 2017.  Her opera, Emmett Till, with composer Mary Watkins, will be presented next year by the Harlem Lyric Theater & Opera Co.

This is the first entry in Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices on Voices4Hillary

A COMPELLING PROPOSAL
Tim Kaine for Hillary VP

By Sarah Kovner

The old adage "that a vice presidential candidate should do no harm" speaks to the choice of Senator Tim Kaine, a moderate non-controversial Democrat.  But I see a more compelling case for choosing the Virginia Senator.

We all know, or should, that before he was a Senator, Kaine was the Governor of Virginia and DNC chairman at the same time, and before that he was Mayor of Richmond.

What most people don't know is that after graduating from Harvard Law School he spent 17 years practicing law in Richmond representing people who had been denied housing opportunities because of their race or disability.

What we also don't know is that the Senator took a break from Harvard to work as a Catholic missionary in Honduras where he learned his fluent Spanish. Indeed, when i saw him in Georgia campaigning for Michelle Nunn in 2014, he was specifically meeting with Spanish-speaking Hispanic entrepreneurs and other community groups.

As a prime architect of President Obama's Iran deal in 2015, Senator Kaine demonstrated his ability to work across party lines with Senator Corker while maintaining his principles of diplomacy first.

I have known Tim Kaine personally since 2009 and I want to say that he is committed to progressive values and works to achieve them in a collaborative way. I think we all believe we need more of that in Washington and indeed in the country as a whole. He also has 100% rating from Planned Parenthood and says that "the right role for government is to let women make their own decision."

And while i can make a case (different though it may be) for Senators Sherrod Brown, Elizabeth Warren or Cory Booker, when Tim Kaine becomes Vice President, his replacement will be chosen by a Democratic Governor. The same cannot be said of the others at a time when we vitally need a Democratic Senate.

And one last thought.  Almost blue Virginia borders on purple North Carolina which could help bring  the Tar Heel State along.

     #####

The indomitable Sarah Kovner is a longtime activist, feminist and Democrat.

Dear Supporters, 

As you can see, we have now renamed this page Voices4Hillary. This renaming is part of a cross-platform social media effort being mounted by The Hillary We Know group. 

More changes will be forthcoming soon, but our intention is to provide the most interesting, informative, useful and stimulating posts on issues affecting America and our political system. Our goal is to elect and support Hillary Clinton. 

Thank you for your support. Every "like" and "share" is a vote for what we do.

Annette Niemtzow, Diane Slaine, Ted Smyth, Editors

Ann Lewis, who has been known to find her way around a political block or two, leads off with the first post under our new name, Voices4Hillary. BLogging for Hillary is now Voices4Hillary. CHOOSING THE NEXT VICE PRESIDENT/HOW IT HAPPENS by Ann F. Lewis begins our series: 
Who Will Hillary Pick? - a Series of Provocative Advocacies About Possible VP Choices.  

Ann was Senior Advisor to Hillary Clinton's 2008 Presidential campaign. She served as White House Director of Communications for President Bill Clinton; as Political Director of the Democratic National Committee and as Chair of the DNC Women's Vote Center.  Here is her inside scoop on how the process of choosing a VP happens.

CHOOSING THE NEXT VICE PRESIDENT
HOW IT HAPPENS by Ann F. Lewis
            
Hillary Clinton won the Democratic nomination for President in 2016 by campaigning for and receiving 15,805,136 votes throughout the primary process.  For those still keeping score, her current delegate vote total is 2,765.  When she announces her Vice Presidential candidate, that person will have received one vote – hers. 

In fact, in recent Democratic party history, the choice for a vice presidential candidate has almost always been made by the Presidential nominee. The exception is Adlai Stevenson in 1956, who threw the nomination open to the convention. John F. Kennedy lost to Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee that year; no one has been inspired to follow his example since. 

It is of course theoretically possible, even after the Presidential nominee has announced her choice, that a majority of the delegates could decide to vote for someone else. It is also theoretically possible that the convention would be welcomed with a solar eclipse. I wouldn't count on either. 

There may be private disagreements:  There was  certainly grumbling in 1940 when word got out that Franklin Delano Roosevelt wanted Secretary of Agriculture Henry Wallace as his Vice President. The grumbling grew so loud that Eleanor Roosevelt – at the urging of Frances Perkins – flew to Chicago to address the delegates. "This is no ordinary time." she told them, urging them to honor the President's choice. And they did. 

Robert Kennedy- the most valued member of his brother's inner circle- was definitely not pleased to learn that John Kennedy had decided on Lyndon Johnson. He made his objections clear- but it was JFK who had the deciding vote. 

So the President's choice it will be. After all, by whatever process the delegates were chosen, they come to the convention agreed in wanting the strongest possible campaign in the fall – a unity of purpose that grows every time Donald Trump opens his mouth! 

What are the political lessons of recent past selections? First, I suggest, forget geography. Lyndon Johnson may have made a geographic difference in 1960, but that kind of Boston to Austin match hasn't worked since (Ask President Dukakis of Massachusetts and his Texas running-mate, Senator Lloyd Bentsen).

Another lesson:  In 1984, Gerry Ferraro made history with courage and grace. The announcement that she was Walter Mondale's choice for Vice-President evoked great enthusiasm within the party –but then set off a roar of press criticism she was not immediately ready to rebut.  Defeating the popular Ronald Reagan was never going to be easy; Gerry deserved a better introduction.
 
We've learned. Once the VP choice was made at the convention; today we expect it to come before,  maximizing the opportunity to make positive news, and enabling the campaign to work with the chosen candidate earlier, so that everyone is prepared for the tsunami of attention to come. 

From the selection of Harry Truman in 1948 to Joe Biden sixty years later, probably the most consistent  factor in vice presidential nominees has been to choose a partner in governing: someone who shares the Presidential nominee's values, and can help enact and implement the Presidential agenda. 

I don't know who the nominee will be this time; but Hillary Clinton has an impressive set of options for her Vice-Presidential choice –leaders who are committed to progressive principles, with  admirable records of public service.  I'm eager to learn her decision! 

Ann F. Lewis was Senior Advisor to Hillary Clinton's 2008 Presidential campaign. She served as White House Director of Communications for President Bill Clinton; as Political Director of the Democratic National Committee and as Chair of the DNC Women's Vote Center.

status_message:
Alison Bernstein, who left her mark in many public places--at the Ford Foundation, at Spelman College, at Rutgers University-- died on June 30. The private loss is incalculable to the many who knew her.

Alison Bernstein, Mo Mowlam, Hillary Clinton
3 Leaders In Sync  By Marie Wilson

This Sunday's New York Times reported the death of Alison Bernstein, an amazing leader who, while during her four decades at the Ford Foundation (1982-2010) placed her bets on so many of the early women's movement activities in the US and around the world.  
 
Our paths crossed in 1984 when I left a political office in Iowa to lead the Ms. Foundation for Women. The foundation was low on cash, and I was thrilled when some of my new colleague invited me for a drink that included one of Ford's top program officers, Alison Bernstein. I'll never forget my awe of this deep voiced, confident woman who ordered Makers Mark Scotch, and kept the table spellbound with her brilliance.
 
At that time and for the next two decades, the US women's movement was one foundation away from welfare: Ford. President Susan Berresford and Allison were often responsible for those of us who survived. 

When 20 years later I realized that the work of our Ms. grantees could not continue if a diversity of women were not in political office, I left the foundation to begin the White House Project where we used the growing conversation about the Presidency to jump start a movement to get a diverse group of women to enter politics up to and including the Presidency.
 
Allison understood our work, and funded us for what became a turning point in our success: a National Press Club gathering, what we called Why Women Matter. With Ford's support we brought women leaders from those countries who were already advancing women's leadership in politics, and US women's groups struggling to do the same into the National Press Club.  
 
One of the leaders was Mo Mowlam, a British MP who played a major role in the peace process in Northern Ireland.  I had heard about Mowlam from women who traveled with Hillary Clinton, and came by to tell me that Mo was astounding.  Mowlam had been diagnosed with cancer, and by that time had lost her hair and wore a wig. When things got too hot, she supposedly just took it off and tossed it across the room.  
 
Mowlam's bravery in bringing the settlement to that war-torn place was legend. When Blair was introduced to celebrate the new peace agreement he got tepid applause. But they raised the roof when Mowlam stood.  
 
I couldn't wait for her to speak at our event that day, but we all had to:  Mowlam dashed into the press club late, but just in time to take the podium.  She was a disheveled mess with fresh coffee stains dripping down her chest.  She had stopped to see Hillary and changed clothes in the cab. But she didn't miss a beat. She looked out over the audience, beat on the podium, and, with the wonderful authority that was hers, barked "Confidence, that's what women need, confidence!"  I have never before or since been as impressed by a female politician as I was at that moment and throughout her address.  She died of cancer soon afterwards. But I will always remember her for her wisdom and bravery and her devotion to Clinton.
 
Allison, Mowlam and Clinton…..three stunning women.We didn't miss out on Alison…she followed up her career at Ford as Director of the Rutgers' Institute for Women's Leadership where she championed a new agenda, including the creation of the Gloria Steinem Endowed Chair in Media, Culture and Feminist Studies.  Nor did we miss out on Mowlam….While the world would have been safer had she lived, her feat in Northern Ireland was historical.
 
And if many of the women of this country and the world have our say, we will not miss out on the step we most need to take in the US by Clinton's election. As Mowlam beat out on that podium then, let's beat on every podium across the US that has any doubts about Clinton as the legacy of Bernstein and Mowlam. Confidence, people, confidence; that's what we need.  
 
Marie Wilson, a pioneer in the women's movement,was President of the Ms Foundation for Women for 20 years; Founder and President Emerita, the White House Project;  Advisory Board Chair, VoteRunLead; creator of Take our Daughters to Work Day; and Athena Fellow, Barnard College.

Frederick Davie, Executive-Vice President of Union Theological Seminary in New York City, writes movingly about Taming the Beast of Bigotry in America

Bigotry in America is real. It is ontological. It has being. Fear and insecurity are its lifeblood. It presents in all forms. Overt. Ugly. Aggressive. Lethal. Subtle. Micro. Genteel. 
 
And we feed our American beast of bigotry with fears of all kinds and arm it with guns, and so it metastasizes into a mass killer of men, women and children.

Consider its impact on the 500 children in the Montessori school where Philando Castile worked; on the daughter of his girlfriend; and on the millions of ritualistically marginalized and economically deprived families of single mothers and their children who are shut off from prosperity and opportunity in America. 
        
We've all heard it.
 
We have nothing against them. 
 
We just don't want them in our schools, our pools, our restaurants, our neighborhoods, our residential spaces, our offices, our beaches, our country clubs, our congregations.
 
This bigotry becomes its most animated, virulent, hateful self when in the presence of blackness. And male blackness seems to trigger in bigotry deadly, uncontrolled spasms, wreaking lethal havoc, again and again and again. Seemingly totally out of control.
 
In the wake of bigotry's lethal orgasmic explosions emerges a national ritual of temporary contrition. 
 
"We can never allow this degree of compulsive bigoted, murderous excess," we solemnly profess with much weeping and wailing and mourning.
 
We promise to reform this bigoted being, which is within our own hearts and minds. Like regretful and worn down addicts, we swear to get It – the beast -- under control, even to root it out. 
 
But then we don't. We never do.
 
And murderous, ole bigotry goes back to masquerading as something else, something more socially acceptable until, with enough time passing, our fears and insecurity stoke again its murderous rage.
 
Hillary Clinton, when President, should elicit the support of former President Obama, the Congressional Black Caucus, other Congressional members of color, progressive members of Congress, enlightened police officials and community leaders to plan, design and implement a set of conversations on race, community/police relations, and what it means to be one United States of America.  These conversations should be monthly in different regions of the country over the course of a year. Followed in subsequent years by bi-annual national convening

And there should be concrete outcomes from these discussions, specific proposals -- and actions -- to reform criminal justice and policing, as well as address the festering educational, economic and social inequality that underlies the beast of bigotry. 

Nothing short of sustained, long-term, intentional, honest, unrelenting, irrepressible engagement will tame this ugly beast. It's all in our hands.
    ###
Fred Davie, Presbyterian minister and Executive VP at Union Seminary NYC, has a career that includes non-profit management and leadership and senior positions in government and philanthropy, with a focus on intersectional issues of community empowerment, racial and criminal justice, LGBTQ rights and interreligious cooperation. He is a graduate of Greensboro College and Yale Divinity School

status_message:
In this important letter,  written in the pain of the recent killings and violence, Hillary seeks to heal the divisions and unite Americans in support of a fairer, respectful and safer society for all. 

Friend -- 

Like so many people across America, I have been following the news of the past few days with horror and grief.

On Tuesday, Alton Sterling, father of five, was killed in Baton Rouge -- approached by the police for selling CDs outside a convenience store. On Wednesday, Philando Castile, 32 years old, was killed outside Minneapolis -- pulled over by the police for a broken tail light.

And last night in Dallas, during a peaceful protest related to those killings, a sniper targeted police officers -- five have died: Brent Thompson, Patrick Zamarripa, Michael Krol, Michael Smith, and Lorne Ahrens. Their names, too, will be written on our hearts.

What can one say about events like these? It's hard to know where to start. For now, let's focus on what we already know, deep in our hearts: There is something wrong in our country.

There is too much violence, too much hate, too much senseless killing, too many people dead who shouldn't be. No one has all the answers. We have to find them together. Indeed, that is the only way we can find them.

Let's begin with something simple but vital: listening to each other.

White Americans need to do a better job of listening when African Americans talk about seen and unseen barriers faced daily. We need to try, as best we can, to walk in one another's shoes. To imagine what it would be like if people followed us around stores, or locked their car doors when we walked past, or if every time our children went to play in the park, or just to the store to buy iced tea and Skittles, we said a prayer: "Please God, don't let anything happen to my baby."

Let's also put ourselves in the shoes of police officers, kissing their kids and spouses goodbye every day and heading off to do a dangerous job we need them to do. Remember what those officers in Dallas were doing when they died: They were protecting a peaceful march. When gunfire broke out and everyone ran to safety, the police officers ran the other way -- into the gunfire. That's the kind of courage our police and first responders show all across America.

We need to ask ourselves every single day: What can I do to stop violence and promote justice? How can I show that your life matters -- that we have a stake in another's safety and well-being?

Elie Wiesel once said that "the opposite of love is not hate -- it's indifference. And the opposite of life is not death -- it's indifference."

None of us can afford to be indifferent toward each other -- not now, not ever. We have a lot of work to do, and we don't have a moment to lose. People are crying out for criminal justice reform. People are also crying out for relief from gun violence. The families of the lost are trying to tell us. We need to listen. We need to act.

I know that, just by saying all these things together, I may upset some people.

I'm talking about criminal justice reform the day after a horrific attack on police officers. I'm talking about courageous, honorable police officers just a few days after officer-involved killings in Louisiana and Minnesota. I'm bringing up guns in a country where merely talking about comprehensive background checks, limits on assault weapons and the size of ammunition clips gets you demonized.

But all these things can be true at once.

We do need police and criminal justice reforms, to save lives and make sure all Americans are treated as equal in rights and dignity.

We do need to support police departments and stand up for the men and women who put their lives on the line every day to protect us.

We do need to reduce gun violence.

We may disagree about how, but surely we can all agree with those basic premises. Surely this week showed us how true they are.

I've been thinking today about a passage from Scripture that means a great deal to me -- maybe you know it, too:

"Let us not grow weary in doing good, for in due season, we shall reap, if we do not lose heart."

There is good work for us to do, to find a path ahead for all God's children. There are lost lives to redeem and bright futures to claim. We must not lose heart.

May the memory of those we've lost light our way toward the future our children deserve.

Thank you, 

Hillary

***

Learn more about Hillary's plans to tackle criminal justice reform: https://www.hillaryclinton.com/issues/criminal-justice-reform/

Learn more about Hillary's plans to prevent gun violence: https://www.hillaryclinton.com/issues/gun-violence-prevention/

status_message:
Like many of us, the journalist and commentator Linda Ellerbee has strong opinions about what has happened in the last 72 hours: Baton Rouge, Minnesota, Dallas. We hope you read and share.

JUST MY OPINION
By Linda Ellerbee
 
All day I've been told — online, on the air, and on the street — how shocked I should be, how outraged, what an atrocity this is. What happened last night in Dallas was horrible — and is never justified, but grief is the right response. Shock is not.
 
What the hell did we expect was going to happen?
 
Dallas was a violent reaction to violence, a blacklash, if you will, against the unarguable fact that for too many years, too many cops have been able to kill too many black citizens and not be held responsible for it, culminating earlier this week in two more young black men killed by police officers. Dallas was no more an atrocity than Louisiana or Minnesota.
 
Dallas was also the unsurprising result of too many damn guns. We cannot have it both ways. We can't point to the 2nd Amendment and say we need an armed citizenry to protect us from a rogue government, then act surprised when an armed citizen attacks what he believes is a nation of rogue cops.
 
There is more than enough grief to go around. Be nice if we could share that today instead of more outrage. More hate. Hate and guns. Guns and hate. We've cooked up a mighty toxic stew, and our pot boileth over.
 
I'm white. I've never had to instruct my son and grandsons how to behave so as not to get themselves killed for having a non-working taillight on a car, or sassing a cop, or simply insisting on their dignity. But I stand with those mothers. I mourn for their dead children. And I mourn for those dead police officers in Dallas. However, blue is not better than black. Cop lives do not matter more than black lives. Life matters.
 
Just my opinion.
 
Here's another. I am for arming everyone in this country.
 
With cell-phone video cameras.
 
It's forcing us to see ourselves in ways journalism never did.
 
Linda Ellerbee

Linda Ellerbee is a well known award winning American journalist who has been explaining tough stuff to adults and children for decades

status_message:
Eleanor and Hillary with Blanche Wiesen Cook
Blogging for Hillary recently had the pleasure of talking with Blanche Wiesen Cook, Distinguished Professor of history at John Jay College in the City University of New York, author of the the best selling biography of Eleanor Roosevelt, volumes I andu II, and the soon-to-be published volume III. Here is what she had to say about the two most activist First Ladies in US History.

What do you think Eleanor would say about the idea of a former First Lady running and ultimately becoming President of the United States?

ER believed that democracy depended on organized movements, activist movements.  She refused to run for office because women were not organized sufficiently to be elected, or respected.  NOW women are organized and we must fortify our movements for change -- as ER encouraged us to do from the l920s forward: door to door, block by block.  

What are your thoughts about moving from First Lady to President?    
What wonderful insider knowledge -- from the WHITE HOUSE to the WHITE HOUSE, with years as secretary of state confronting the most perilous global issues.  A politician, a diplomat, a leader for our time --  a time of danger and peril requiring keen judgment, agile teamwork, profound understanding.

What qualities do you think Hillary shares with Eleanor?   
Like many strong women attorneys, educators, leaders in all fields, WOMEN are the BEST MULTI-TASKERS!  Wives, mothers, organizers, agitators.  Specifically, ER and HRC share a belief that peace requires economic security, education and training for all; full employment, health care and housing, dignity and respect.  The l935 social security act was meant to have medical security -- what we now call "single payer " which exists in all industrial nations; the AMA lobbied it to death from FDR to DDE -- when ER and her life-long friend Esther Lape lobbied for national health;  subsequently, the  AMA controlled health reinsurance corporations limited the vision of  HRC & Obama; now we must go forward -- on all these progressive fronts -- ER called for FREE public higher education as early as l943; she championed continuing life-long adult education for re-training, independence, personal empowerment!  Debt free education is a human right -- HRC and ER share the best values for the future, a people's economy without a predator class of truly greedy folks who  own and control elections in order to plunder democracy, a harmonious environment to sustain life on this one world we all do happen to share.

Many of us have been surprised by the level of racism that reared its ugly head aimed at President Obama during his presidency.  Do you think sexism will do the same during a Hillary presidency?
Racism and sexism are at large, world-wide; we must end the abuse of women and minorities world-wide;  our movements for peace and freedom, women's rights and human rights must be fortified in every community to battle the scourge of horror and hate which defines the 21st century.

Why are you supporting Hillary Clinton?   
HRC is the candidate of VISION and HOPE!  for justice, equity, human rights and DIGNITY FOR ALL

Blanche Wiesen Cook, historian and journalist is distinguished professor, John Jay College & The Graduate Center, CUNY; author of CRYSTAL EASTMAN ON WOMEN AND REVOLUTION, THE DECLASSIFIED EISENHOWER: A DIVIDED LEGACY OF PEACE & POLITICAL WARFARE, and ELEANOR ROOSEVELT Vols l, II, and soon III, which will be published by Viking- Penquin on November 1.

status_message:
Hillary, Now More Than Ever

By John Howell

Each week for the last month, I've sat down to write about why voting for Hillary Clinton for President is the single most important step to be taken toward a better future than the present we're seeing now. And every week, some major event has crashed into my thoughts and disrupted them: terrorist attacks, the EU's immigration and political crisis, and most recently, the collapse of the polity of the United Kingdom, the one that most resembles ours.

It's hard to resist quoting Yeat's "The Second Coming"—the common trope for such times since 1968—but it really does appear that "the center cannot hold," and that rough beasts are slouching toward us from every direction. And what rough beasts: nationalist (read "racist") political movements on the rise throughout Europe, extremist fanatics bent on wreaking global terrorist mayhem, and, of course, that one-man wrecking crew of U.S. polity, Mr. Trump.

Against this bleak landscape, I see one possibility for at least an effective holding action against such serious threats, and just maybe, for some progress to be made: President Hillary Clinton.

It's all about perspective. Enlarge the field of vision by looking backward at the sweep of history for a sobering moment: you could start with the 1930s if you want to find unsettling parallels to today's events. Global economic distress, a rise in violence, fascist politics driven by ideologies of ethnic and national righteousness, a failure of progressive leadership to persuade general populations, an angry pushback against all authority—pick your power point topic and you can make several slides of connections between the decade that set the stage for the most destructive event in human history—World War II— and today.

So what should we do? Read Freud (especially Civilization and its Discontents—published 1930, by the way) to prepare for the reality of the worst outcome? Yes, but that's not all.

Looking at the Big Picture, thinking beyond issues of character pros and cons, considering long-ago decisions and votes on complex issues, and acknowledging the considerable baggage of Bill, it's pretty obvious to me (has been since the beginning of the current campaign) that the best choice for the kind of clear-headed, fact- driven, realpolitik leadership that the country needs at this time is embodied by Hillary Clinton's experience, skills, and above all, her dedication of her life to public service. She, like many other smart, talented, and ambitious people, didn't have to choose the increasingly nasty arena of public life to earn a successful life. Her 37 years of political activity (Bill Clinton was elected Governor of Arkansas in 1979) should be counted as a major credit toward the country's highest office.

In this current media climate, in which headlines about "presumptive candidate" Thomas Jefferson would be "slave-holder, draft dodger, and mixed-race fornicator," instead of "brilliant polymath, visionary politician, and superb philosopher on the big issues," it's no surprise that the 24/7 cable news-driven machine spews negatives about Hillary Clinton on a regular basis. Ignore them. Any candidate with as long a public life as hers will own mistakes, arguable choices, and off- track fixations. Any candidate with the ambition to become president will have strong personality and behavioral tics (seriously "normal" human beings do not strive for high-level leadership positions in American politics). It's time to acknowledge the complexities of high achievers in our political realm as is common in other major public areas (sports, technology, entertainment).

A note for you wonderfully idealistic, thoroughly energetic, and altogether admirable Bernie-ites: if you do NOT vote for Hillary Clinton out of ideology and/or spite, you will see any chance for any part of the Sanders' program be buried under a President Trump, whose election you will be enabling by not supporting the other viable choice. Likewise, conscience voting for third party candidates, no matter how reasonable and self-satisfying, is a luxury that these perilous times can ill afford (c.f. the case of the President Gore we did not get, partly due to Mr. Nader's Quixote-ism). With President Hillary Clinton, you will have a shot at putting into action some, if not all, of a progressive program that has been effectively put into play.

So now, just do the right and good thing and vote for Hillary Clinton for President. Once she's in office, the real work of righting a wobbling world begins.

           ####

John Howell is Editorial Director for 3BL Media, overseeing five international news and distribution websites; a partner in Howell Farms, Malden, MO, a 75 year-old family agribusiness; and a long-time supporter of Hillary and Bill Clinton.

status_message:
Please read and share this very moving and personal tribute from Catherine Wilson
Forty Million Invisible Lives, One Visible Voice
Hillary and the Alzheimer's Caregivers

"Caregivers are invisible".

Those were the opening remarks by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at a caregivers' conference in August, 2008.

Despite having dropped out of the Presidential race that morning, Senator Clinton still attended this event at the Jawonio center in Yonkers, New York, to call for federal funding for her "Lifespan Respite Care Act". The Lifespan Respite Care Act would provide caregivers with much needed breaks from their overwhelming responsibilities. As Senator Clinton reminded the audience that day, "When the individual who needs care is housebound, the caregiver is also housebound". Like the caregivers she was addressing, even though she had just suffered a very public and personal loss, Senator Clinton did not take "time out" from her responsibilities. She knew there was no respite on this issue. She advocated that day for individuals who had no voice, just as she had been doing for over thirty years.

I had been asked by the Alzheimer's Association to speak that day on behalf of Alzheimer's caregivers. My own mother had been sadly diagnosed with cognitive dementia a few years prior and I was caring for her 24/7 in my home. Prior to my mother's diagnosis, I had been married, was raising two children, had a career as an accountant, and was Treasurer of the local P.T.A. Within days of moving my mother into my home, I lost the first of many jobs.

Within weeks, my children became adept at taking care of themselves, including figuring out how to get themselves to school, soccer matches, and track meets. Within months, I had become an expert in medications, brain scans, Medicare rules, and EMS services. Within a year, I was isolated. I was also now a single mother, like so many in my situation, so I had to handle all of my increasing responsibilities alone. My only contact with the outside world was my children, my closest friends, my immediate neighbors, and the medical community. Former associates, coworkers, and acquaintances, disappeared. Despite being on the brink of bankruptcy, there were no PTA fund raisers for me or the other caregivers in our community. When I finally ran into a PTA member years later in the supermarket, she looked shocked to see me and exclaimed "I thought you died". No one thought to actually check on me during those years to see how I was doing and if I needed help. I had become invisible to the outside world.

But I was not invisible to Senator Clinton.

Senator Clinton's legislation revealed that millions of individuals in the U.S. (latest estimates are over 43 million) care for one or more family members or friends who are chronically ill, disabled, or terminally ill, and that nearly twenty- five percent of the elderly require help for their daily needs due to multiple chronic disabling conditions. As Senator Clinton noted in her legislation, approximately seventy-five percent of family caregivers are women, and while the caregiver role is personally rewarding, it can result in substantial emotional, physical, and financial hardship.

The Lifespan Respite Care Act was signed into law in December 2006, authorizing Congress to spend $53.3 million for respite for caregivers. But as of August 2008, Congress had yet to approve any funding. Senator Clinton was in Jawonio that day, facing an audience of caregivers, medical professionals, advocates, politicians, and the media, to press the case for funding. The response by the media was overwhelming silence. That night, television stations broadcasted Paris Hilton poolside in a bikini in a Presidential campaign spoof. Any coverage of the Jawonio event simply acknowledged Senator Clinton's attendance but focused on her role after the campaign. CNN's website merely notes that "Clinton was in Yonkers, New York for a family and caregivers event". There were no reports of the testimony of the desperate caregivers pleading their case that day. Even to the media, we caregivers were invisible.

This April, I met Secretary Clinton at an event on the campaign trail and seized the opportunity to speak with her about Alzheimer's and caregivers. Secretary Clinton immediately confirmed to me that she will continue her fight to provide services for family caregivers. Her platform for President specifies plans to invest $2 billion per year in research for Alzheimer's and related disorders. None of the other candidates had even drafted a plan to combat this devastating disease, nor did they have any specific proposals to help overburdened family caregivers.

Sadly my own mother has since passed away. I am now a voice for my invisible peers, advocating for them in Albany, New York and on Capitol Hill. But with presumptive Democratic Presidential nominee Hillary Rodham Clinton firmly in their corner, millions of invisible caregivers finally have a very visible voice.
        ###
Catherine Wilson writes a weekly column on financial and advocacy issues. She has long been an advocate on the needs of the elderly and disabled and their 43 million caregivers.
