status_message:
Blogging for Hillary's Tim Davis recently interviewed Gerry Laybourne, one of television's most powerful women about being a Democrat and supporting Hillary.  After serving as President of Disney/ABC cable networks, she left to found the women's programming network, Oxygen Media.

Why are you a Democrat?

Ironically, on both sides of my family, my mother's mother was the  head of the Republican Party in North Dakota, and my father's father was a Brooklyn Congressman – I think the only Republican ever elected out of Brooklyn in the 1920's. My parents grew up amidst Republican values and then began to question them in the 1950's.  My mother became a very big Democrat.  We were the only Democrats in a Republican neighborhood so I was the only kid supporting Adlai Stevenson.  It was a values lesson in our family.  We learned what it was to be a Democrat.  Being a Democrat was caring about everybody.  Being a Democrat was caring about schools. Being a Democrat was about paying our fair share of taxes.  Being a Democrat was about Civil Rights.

How did that differ from Republicans?
Honestly in those days I do not remember such a big difference as today.  We were all about rebuilding America and our economy.  Republicans were more concerned about keeping taxes low and building up the military.

What was your first Presidential Campaign?
Adlai Stevenson.  I was tormented.  Kids would write in the dust on our bumper "I Like Ike." They would put "I Like Ike" stickers on my books.  I was 8 years old.  But I stood up.  I've been a fighting Democrat since I was 8.
 
Talk a little about your family.
I have two sisters and a brother.  But I have 27 cousins who are mostly Republicans.
 
How does that work?
You know, we all love each other.  We're all look alike especially my cousin Lisa and I. Our values are so close but she was raised a Republican and I was raised a Democrat. Our differences are probably closer to  the world we grew up in than the world we inhabit.

Your values are similar but you are basically on opposite sides of the political spectrum? Lisa Likely will vote for Hillary because values have been breached in this election. When it comes down to basic human dignity, I think there is going to be a lot of crossing over. I think you see it on both sides. 

I think the media and especially social media are primary villains in this story.  And I hope we can turn social media around to being a hero.  Social media makes it very easy for people to be snide and snarky and let out deep feelings they may have about thinks like: How come women get to do these things?  Am I going to get a job if women are going to get my jobs?   There's some very basic negative things coming out in our society and my orientation has always been: Let's lift everybody up.  That has always been the central message of Hillary. Let's figure out how we fix education.  Let's figure out how people get to college who have never had access to college.  Let's deal with income inequality. I am more committed than ever to get more involved in prison reform because I see it.  I see what it's done to our country.  We've turned prisons into a big businesses.  Now, I have been a big business woman, but always with values.  I was lucky enough to work on things like Nickelodeon where if you didn't have values, you had no business being there.  But when we go pure business and pure profit, we miss out on everything this country is about and we end up in the state we're in right now.  If people had the community orientation to build a society where our infrastructure works and there's a chance for everyone to be in the middle class, we would be a different country.
 
Do you see this election as hope versus fear?

It is definitely that.  I think reality television has had an impact.  I think there is no way Donald Trump would be the Republican nominee if it hadn't been for The Apprentice. I've always been afraid of reality TV because of what it take people to people's to the lowest common denominator very quickly.  I think that people look at it from a sense of "Well, at least I'm not that bad!" But then you have the consequence of somebody like Donald Trump, who really hasn't been a business success – except for reality TV.  When you read the front page of a newspaper, you're not reading hopeful articles.  You're reading about what's falling apart.  What's not happening.  But I am an optimist.  Maybe that's why I'm a Democrat.  I wake up thinking that everything is possible.  And I feel so much better when I'm working for the greater good than when I'm just working for the almighty dollar.
 
You were responsible for Linda Ellerbee doing Nick News on Nickelodeon. She spoke to kids in a very positive way.  What impact do you think that had on those children today?  

It's funny that you mention this because when Linda and I talked about starting Nick News, I said to her my goal is to raise up better candidates. That was the underlying purpose of Nick News.  We were training these kids to be engaged in the world, to want to be involved in the world, to want to be good citizens, and frankly to run for office. Nick News just celebrated its 25th Anniversary.  We haven't yet hit that age when a kid running for President would have been old enough to have been impacted by Nick News. But one of the things that was so exciting for me about Nick News is that it put everything into context.   We weren't breaking news.  We tried to explain the news.  We put it into a story.  We made it emotional.  We helped kids learn to care about things.  Like when we covered AIDS with Magic Johnson.  Unfortunately, Nick News was cancelled this year.  

In Part 2 of BlogTalk Gerry will talk about Hillary Clinton

status_message:
These important insights on Hillary's Commitment to Human Rights are by Michael Posner, former Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights Democracy and Labor, now a Professor at NYU Stern School of Business and co-Director of the Center for Business and Human Rights.

Clinton's Commitment, Tenacity and Smart Diplomacy Enabled Real Progress in Human Rights.

Last week in San Diego Hillary Clinton urged Americans to remain "true to our values."  She stressed,  "We never, ever stop trying to make our country and world a better place," a theme she has sounded often throughout her campaign.  Some will dismiss this as campaign-generated rhetoric. In fact it's a commitment that is central to who she is as a person and what has motivated her decades of public service.  I say this with great confidence because I had a front row seat during Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State.
  
 From 2009 until 2013 I served as the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights Democracy and Labor, her point person on issues where America's values are tested every day.  She recruited me to come to the State Department after I had spent more than three decades as a human rights advocate outside of government, including as long-time director of Human Rights First.  I came into government believing that other U.S. interests – political, economic and security – often would trump our commitments to human rights.  I also had been warned that even getting the attention of senior policy-makers on human rights and democracy issues would be a constant struggle.  My experience working with Secretary Clinton offered a powerful counter-narrative.
 
From day one I saw Hillary Clinton's personal commitment to human rights, a commitment that flows naturally from her lifetime of advocacy for the rights of women, children and those most vulnerable in our world.  This commitment manifests itself in her involvement in individual cases and in advancing broader shifts in policy.  Too often senior officials will pay public homage to promoting human rights in the abstract, but decline to raise specific issues in private meetings with foreign officials.  Clinton did just the opposite and because of her commitment, tenacity and smart diplomacy, we made real progress. 
 
In Uzbekistan, for example, in December 2010 she successfully pressed President Karimov for the release of Yusuf Juma, the country's poet laureate who was languishing in a dismal jail.  I was with her in that tense meeting in Tashkent and marveled at her tenacious advocacy on Mr Juma's behalf.  We had important security issues on the agenda, and it would have been easy to say that raising Juma's case was a bridge too far.  But Clinton was determined not just to raise his case but to press successfully for Juma's release.
 
On a broader scale in 2011 and 2012 we made the release of more than 1100 political prisoners an essential element of U.S. re-engagement with Burma. U.S. policy-makers were eager to take advantage of an opening in diplomatic relations after more than 50 years.  The Burmese government, still dominated by the military, was deeply resistant to the release of student activists, labor leaders and others who had opposed its policies.  But on a visit to Burma in December 2011 Secretary Clinton kept this issue on the U.S. agenda and provided the leadership my colleagues and I needed to keep pressing for these releases.  By the end of 2012, the government had freed more than 1100 political prisoners, including a number who had been in prison for a decade or more.  While other rights challenges in Burma remain unresolved, such as ongoing ethnic conflicts and discrimination against the Rohingya, Secretary Clinton's leadership on the prisoner issue was decisive.
 
More broadly, Hillary Clinton's lifelong commitment to fighting discrimination motivated her to raise the global bar in fighting attacks on the LGBT community. This was her deliberate commitment from day one and it culminated with her memorable human rights day speech at the United Nations in Geneva in 2011.  As I stood in the back of the room and watched her deliver that powerful speech to more than 1000 diplomats and others, my pride in being a part of the United States government was never greater.  In that historic moment Hillary Clinton proclaimed that LGBT rights are human rights, and she announced a broader program to make that commitment a central element of U.S. foreign policy.  These are the types of actions that defined Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State and its what she means when she says we must never stop working to make America and the world a better place. And this will be a part of her agenda when she is elected President in November.

Michael Posner after his swearing in by Secretary of State Clinton.

Michael Posner, former Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights Democracy and Labor, is now a Professor at NYU Stern School of Business and co-Director of the Center for Business and Human Rights.

status_message:
The Next President Will Shape the Supreme Court for a Generation  

In the first of a series of interviews, the indomitable Sarah Kovner, longtime activist, feminist and Democrat speaks with Blogging for Hillary Editor, Ted Smyth

Why are you a Democrat?
It might sound corny, but I believe in social justice where everyone has an equal shot. When I was at High School in South Orange, NJ in the early fifties, I was struck by the absence of equality and was drawn to the civil rights movement. 

When was your first Presidential campaign?  
Adlai Stevenson in 1952; what appealed to us was his intelligence, commitment to justice and his sense of humor. We knocked on doors, went to rallies and learned the importance of getting out the vote. This was a time when nuclear war seemed a real possibility and Senator Joe McCarthy was stirring up fear and bigotry.
What is the most effective way to help in campaigns?
Nothing is more important than speaking directly to friends, neighbors and co-workers about why you support the candidate. In addition, join the campaign office to volunteer in canvassing for votes, knocking on doors, making telephone calls.
What did you learn from the 1968 campaign?  
I was co-chair of the Gene McCarthy New York State campaign and we leveraged the creative talent of New Yorkers to draw attention to Gene's anti-war position. Unfortunately, the Democratic Party was very divided at the convention in August of 1968 and the continuation of those divisions resulted in the election of Richard Nixon, with all the terrible consequences for America that followed. The lesson for today is to realize that we Democrats have a lot more in common. Let unity come from agreement on issues and we should not get separated by personality politics. There is just too much at stake for America.

When did you first meet Hillary?
I first met Hillary in 1992 when Bill was running for President. We were blown away by her ability to speak in paragraphs about important issues such as health care, women's rights, job growth. We knew of her strong record at the Children's Defense Fund but she was really impressive to meet.

Give some examples of why you trust and like Hillary.
Hilary is very thoughtful and genuine, she is kind to the people who work for her, and they are really enthusiastic about her. She is honest and direct; when I spoke to her about her vote on the Iraq war she listened carefully and gave her point of view. She is very approachable and genuinely interested in people and learning from them and finding solutions to problems. What really defines Hillary is a passion for public service and improving society.  

What was your role in the Bill Clinton Administration?
I was Special Assistant to Secretary Shalala at HHS from 1993 to 2001. I focused on women's issues and remember the critical leadership role Hillary played for women's rights around the world, especially at the Beijing Women's Conference in 1995. 

Why is it crucial to elect Hillary?
If I were only allowed to name one thing, it would be the Supreme Court. There is one vacancy now and perhaps two to three more during the next Presidential term. The next President will shape the Supreme Court for a generation or more affecting women's right to choose, voting rights, environmental rights, climate change, worker's rights, everything. If we don't elect Hillary we will lose on every issue we care about.
Another reason is that when you elect a Democratic President you bring in about 7,000 individuals to government who support our causes on behalf of working families and the middle class. The opposite happens when a Republican is in the White House, when equal rights and growth and jobs and family rights are all neglected in favor of the establishment and elites.

You are a super delegate, how did that happen and what are your duties?
Most of the super delegates are elected member of Congress or Governors. I was appointed because I am a member of the Democratic National Committee. One of our roles is to vote at the Convention.

status_message:
Elect a Progressive Who Can Unlock Washington Gridlock

Blogging for Hillary Editor, Ted Smyth, recently sat down with Marie Wilson, a pioneer in the women's movement, President of the Ms Foundation for Women for 20 years, Founder and President Emerita, the White House Project, Advisory Board Chair, VoteRunLead, creator of Take our Daughters to Work Day and Athena Fellow, Barnard College.

You have done amazing things to advance the role of women in leadership since the 1970's, where do you think you had the most impact?

The White House Project, which trained over 15,000 diverse women to run for public office across the country. This is one of the most pressing issues of our time; to encourage more women to enter politics. I sincerely believe that women can help bring people together on the core issues that affect all of us, from creating good-paying jobs, affordable education, healthcare and decent childcare. For example, we've seen how women in the Senate and the Supreme Court have been able to reach across the political divide.

What are the major obstacles remaining for women's equality?

Many in America still see a woman's role as limited to being a wife and mother. We are far behind other developed countries, which have excellent childcare so that both parents can share the work both in and  outside the home. That's why Hillary's plan for universal preschool for America's children is so important. Despite research showing its benefits, only about half of the roughly 8 million 3- and 4- year olds in the U.S. are enrolled in pre-K, with only one in four enrolled in publicly funded pre-K. In addition, workers in every other developed country are entitled to paid leave for newborn care; under Hillary's plan, any worker could take up to 12 weeks of paid leave in order to care for a newborn or sick relative.

If you were a young woman coming out of college today, what would you focus on?

I would go into political leadership. Young women should start by running for School Board, the Parks Commission, then run for the City Council and move on to the State Legislature. If we don't have women in political leadership, nothing will change.

What are young people saying to you about the election?

So many young people admire Hillary and identify with her struggle over the years for fairness and a level playing field for working men and women. Many of them see this as the most important election of their lifetime as we confront the real danger of a Trump presidency. Many young men and women also want to ensure that the political movement started by Bernie continues after the election. In the past, young people have been fired up by elections and then have seen no role for themselves when the election is over. That's actually when the real work of wrestling with Congress will begin, and we will need a national movement to drive all the reforms that Hillary and Bernie agree on.

How important is it to elect Hillary?

Extremely important!  Look, the definition of a progressive is someone who wants to make progress toward a more just and fair country and world. That's who Hillary is, and always has been-- a committed progressive. We have a once-in a-lifetime opportunity to elect a President who not only believes passionately in social justice, but who also has the political skills and toughness to unlock Washington gridlock. The fact that Hillary is also a woman is just icing on the cake.

status_message:
Ni Neart go Cur le Cheile (Strength in Unity)

By Ted Smyth, Editor, Blogging for Hillary

We Irish know about the emotional gratification of division (Brendan Behan used to joke that the first item on the agenda of any new Irish organization was the split) but we also know the cost in lives and lost opportunity.  The question now facing progressive forces in America is how quickly can we unite in support of Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Presidential nominee of the Democratic Party,  to ensure four more years of progressive politics in America and the defeat of extremist Trump policies? Because America is so closely divided between Democrats and Republicans, it only takes a small number of progressives to stay at home for a spoiler effect. In 2000, Ralph Nader took 97,000 votes in Florida. If they had gone to Gore, it would have meant no recount, no President George W. Bush and no Iraq war.  

Many millennials may not be aware that Richard Nixon was elected in 1968 because the Dems could not bring themselves to unite behind their nominee. America paid for that indulgence with corruption at the highest levels  and the prolonging of a bloody war in Vietnam.

President Obama today endorsed Hillary and urged Democrats to unite. In a video we posted below, Obama said, "I don't think there's ever been someone so qualified to hold this office."  He also praised Bernie for an "incredible campaign". As we approach the Democratic Convention next month in Philadelphia, it is important to remember what Hillary and Bernie  have in common and why they both represent the best in the American tradition of fair play for all. They both agree that our political and economic system favors the very rich and powerful. They both have similar policies to create a level playing field to end stagnant wages, unemployment and the constant squeeze on the middle class. They both have mobilized millions of men and women of all backgrounds, ages and races to fight for a better and fairer America.
.
We must now come together to support  a new social partnership that stimulates economic growth and creates good jobs, that nominates Supreme Court judges who protect human rights and women's rights, that fights climate change and guarantees affordable healthcare and education.

These goals are worth fighting for, and - to win - the first item on our agenda in July must be unity.

If you would like to contribute a blog please messenger me.
